CITY OF SALISBURY WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT
                      RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
                       EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

     a.   The City of Salisbury Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) has developed an Emergency
     Response Plan which complies with OSHA's 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety
     Management standard and the US EPA's Emergency Response Program.  The plan
     provides employees guidance on what to do in case of a chemical discharge emergency.  It
     is used by the WWTP when training and preparing for a chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide
     leak.  The Salisbury WWTP has a very strict overall approach to chemical safety.  All of
     our employees and our Hazmat team are annually trained to respond to a chemical
     emergency reminding them that safety is the most important element when protecting
     themselves and the community.

     b.   The City of Salisbury WWTP is responsible for the treatment of the wastewater within the 
     boundaries of the city and additional annexed areas of approximately 12.88 square miles in
     size.  The wastewater plant treats approximately 5 million gallons per day of wastewater
     and maintains 151.07 miles of interceptor collection lines.  The WWTP is located at 1142
     Marine Road in Salisbury, MD.  The Wicomico River runs behind our facility where we
     discharge our effluent.  The WWTP uses chlorine primarily for disinfection and sulfur
     dioxide for dechlorination.  These chemicals are stored in 1-ton cylinders that are housed
     in one main building.  The building also holds chlorinators/sulfonators, electric panels and
     safety equipment.  The maximum amounts of chlorine and sulfur dioxide handled are
     24,000 lbs. (12 1-ton cylinders) each.

     c.   The City of Salisbury WWTP has prepared an offsite consequence analysis for chlorine
     and sulfur dioxide releases including a worst-case scenario and an alternative release
     scenario.  The results are as follows:

WORST-CASE SCENARIO FOR CHLORINE

     Category: Toxic gas-Liquefied under pressure
     Wind Speed: 1.5 meters/second (3.4 miles/hour)
     Stability Class: F
     Air Temperature: 77 degrees F (25 degrees C)
     Quantity Released: 2000 pounds
     Release Duration: 10 minutes
     Release Rate: 110 pounds/minute
     Mitigation Measures: Release in enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air
     Topography: Urban Surroundings (many obstacles in immediate area)
     Toxic Endpoint: 0.0087 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2
     Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint: 0.9 miles (1.4 kilometers)

     The chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems have both active and passive protective measures
including the following: (1) a sealed building located at a low elevation (passive); (2) pressure
relief valves that discharge to a safe location within the contact basin (active); (3) leak detection
equipment (active), and (4) automatic building vent closure and sodium hydroxide scrubber
system (active).

     The event of our worst-case scenario is highly unlikely due to our trained personnel in
operations and safety as well as the fact that our scrubber system is extremely reliable.

     d.   The City of Salisbury WWTP has developed a general accidental release prevention
     program which is based on the following components:

        A thorough and up-to-date preventative maintenance program.
       Use of advanced safety equipment in our chlorine/sulfur

dioxide building.
       A staff of skilled and well-trained operators.
       A list of specific operation procedures that must be followed exactly.
       Frequent review of our equipment and procedures making sure that the task is safe for     
          the operators, the others near the chlorine/sulfur dioxide building and the community           
    surrounding the plant. 
       A process safety management and risk management audit.

     The Salisbury WWTP also takes chemical-specific prevention steps such as training the
operators thoroughly in their tasks of receiving, changing and maintaining chlorine and sulfur
dioxide cylinders (including specific training about the awareness of these chemicals) and making
sure that all operators wear respiratory protection when working with the chlorine and sulfur
dioxide cylinders.

     e.   There has been no accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide at the Salisbury WWTP
     in the last five years.

     f.   The procedures in the City of Salisbury WWTP's Chemical Emergency Response Plan will
     be initiated anytime there is a hazardous chemical leak or chemical spill.  The procedures
     were developed as specific guidelines to follow in the event of this type of emergency. 
     There are many steps to follow in order to get personnel out of the plant safely and have
     the Hazmat team control the leak.  These include: emergency alarms, plant evacuation,
     notification of response personnel and agencies, assembling and moving of equipment,
     leak isolation and containment, repairs and termination of the incident.  Once the incident
     is terminated, there is an incident critique and post incident equipment preparation.

     g.   The City of Salisbury WWTP has made some planned changes to improve safety for
     ourselves and the community.  They are as follows:

       Implement an annual refresher course on all of the procedures to be followed when          
      working with/around chlor

ine and sulfur dioxide.
       Implement a tank inspection program to check for leaks and cracks when new tanks are   
             brought in.
       Implement inspection of truck chocks as part of the leak inspection program.
       Implement a 30 day hoist inspection program.
       Implement hoist training sessions annually.
       Implement examination of the flexible line as part of the new inspection program.
       Implement annual replacement of the flexible line.
       Redesign the chlorine/sulfur dioxide room to plan for better operator access.
       Install a permanent water line.
       Install a fire alarm in the control building.
       Implement operator checks of heaters (when they are being used) to check for correct      
          building temperature.
       Replace plastic pipe with steel (discharge manifold from vacuum regulator).
       Implement annual refresher training on our facility's Chemical Emergency Response         
       Plan.
       Research the possibility of getting automatic shut-off valves that will close in case of a     
           leak to eliminate all four tanks from being expelled.
